tweets.text: walked into my pizza spot and asked for 2 plain slices and in that very instant the guy was pulling a fresh pie out of the oven, I hope you all have an equally blessed friday afternoon

the bing announcement is fascinating because Microsoft is now piping in realtime search results into their LLM- which is cool, but the average person still can't do it (in Microsoft's vision, they probably never can)
anyway, most of the tools you use every day make it extremely difficult to get the data you want out in plaintext quickly without writing code or spinning up infrastructure right now

so, if I were a founder looking to create the future of LLM-powered AI, I would look to build that piping/glue instead of one-shot products- the person who figures out how to centralize, summarize, and serve personal information to the robot with high user control wins, imo

so basically to unlock the power of LLMs, you need to get good summary data of everything you do in plaintext, essentially piping the output of your various tools (figma layers, to do list items, calendar) to the robot to inform your questions- essentially unix piping
whats the easiest/cheapest way to turn my 300-episode archive of my favorite podcast into transcribed text
gotta say I do kinda miss going places and doing things, that was fun

@BrandyZadrozny @oneunderscore__ in a world where success can be measured by many things, to me this is the pinnacle and a testament to the important work that you both do - proud to know you

for example I am thinking of reworking my photoblog and building it to work almost entirely off EXIF data so the input is just .jpgs
my obsession with prototypes has morphed into an obsession with making things with the oldest and most resilient technologies around so I don't have to do things again

@YAN0 @jbenton if you really wanna know, it's because most networks don't see data visualization as different or harder than other "graphics" (like photo illustrations or just photos or maps with text) and so they have designers with no data experience being sent spreadsheets by producers

I have struggled a lot to define who I am to the world, designer, developer, coder, whatever. I keep coming back to hacker. I just make stuff exist. I hack things into existence. Nothing more than that.

But the best hackers (and journalists!) are people with a set of explorational processes that are comfortable with unfamiliar systems - almost the direct opposite of knowing everything. Hackers understand people and the general spirit that our machines move in and learn the rest.
Some people think a hacker is someone who knows everything about every different technology and technique… the hacker knows secret knowledge and deploys it at the perfect time in the perfect way
"No fake news, or your money back."
